docs.snippet: A group of Falkland Islanders have asked the British Government to evacuate the local population before hostilities break out there, and Britain has asked the International Red Cross to take ''an interest'' in the fate of the Falkland Islanders.  ...
docs.lead_paragraph: A group of Falkland Islanders have asked the British Government to evacuate the local population before hostilities break out there, and Britain has asked the International Red Cross to take ''an interest'' in the fate of the Falkland Islanders. The request for evacuation was contained in a letter from prominent Falkland Islanders, but a spokesman for the Falkland Government here disowned the appeal, saying it was not an official one because it was not signed by any elected official of the Falkland Islands Government.

headline.main: London Help Is Sought To Evacuate Falklands

docs.snippet: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.  arrived here tonight and said the Reagan Administration's improved relations with Argentina were ''a good basis'' on which to resolve the Falkland Islands crisis.   Mr. Haig, however, arriving from London in...
docs.lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. arrived here tonight and said the Reagan Administration's improved relations with Argentina were ''a good basis'' on which to resolve the Falkland Islands crisis. Mr. Haig, however, arriving from London in the hope of averting a possible war between Argentina and Britain, cited last week's United Nations Security Council resolution as the foundation for a diplomatic solution. The resolution calls for the Argentines to withdraw their troops from the disputed South Atlantic island, but the resolution was opposed by Argentina. Argentina says it will not withdraw, as Britain demands, until Britain recognizes Argentine soverignty over the islands and its right to administer them.

headline.main: HAIG, IN BUENOS AIRES, SAYS U.S. TIES WITH ARGENTINA FORM BASIS FOR TALKS

byline.original: By EDWARD SCHUMACHER, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: John Lithgow and Dianne Wiest, who is now appearing as Desdemona in ''Othello'' at the Winter Garden, will star in Christopher Durang's ''Beyond Therapy,'' which will open at the Brooks Atkinson Theater on May 24. The comedy, about some therapists...
docs.lead_paragraph: John Lithgow and Dianne Wiest, who is now appearing as Desdemona in ''Othello'' at the Winter Garden, will star in Christopher Durang's ''Beyond Therapy,'' which will open at the Brooks Atkinson Theater on May 24. The comedy, about some therapists and their patients, was done by the Phoenix Theater last year, with Sigourney Weaver and Stephen Collins in the leads. Mr. Durang has since rewritten it. Joining Mr. Lithgow and Miss Wiest will be Kate McGregor-Stewart, Peter Michael Goetz and Jack Gilpin, with Miss McGregor-Stewart and Mr. Gilpin repeating the roles they did in the earlier production. Mr. Goetz was last on Broadway in ''Ned and Jack.'' ''Beyond Therapy'' will be directed by John Madden and produced by Warner Theater Productions and FDM Productions. Cecilia Hart will take over Miss Wiest's role in ''Othello'' on Tuesday.

docs.snippet: The European Common Market approved a total ban on imports from Argentina today as the hour approached for the imposition of Britain's naval blockade on Argentine shipping off the Falkland Islands.   The economic sanctions, adopted at a meeting in...
docs.lead_paragraph: The European Common Market approved a total ban on imports from Argentina today as the hour approached for the imposition of Britain's naval blockade on Argentine shipping off the Falkland Islands. The economic sanctions, adopted at a meeting in Brussels, were the sternest punitive measures taken by the 10-nation European Economic Community in its 25-year history. Officials said the ban on imports, along with a cutoff of arms sales to Argentina approved Friday, could be imposed as early as Wednesday if legal documents were completed in time. A Surprising Victory British politicians were somewhat surprised by what amounted to a diplomatic coup in their efforts to force Argentina to pull its troops out of the Falklands, which were occupied a week ago.

headline.main: EUROPEANS ENDING ARGENTINE IMPORTS IN FALKLAND CRISIS

byline.original: By R.W. APPLE Jr., Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: In the first official report on conditions in the Argentine-occupied Falkland Islands, a former colonial administrator told the British Government today that the population there was facing no serious hardships.   The official, Richard Baker, was...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the first official report on conditions in the Argentine-occupied Falkland Islands, a former colonial administrator told the British Government today that the population there was facing no serious hardships. The official, Richard Baker, was deported today along with a number of his senior aides. They were among a group of 31 Britons and 4 Canadians, about 15 of them children, who arrived in Montevideo, Uruguay, on a regular Aerolineas Argentinas flight. From there, Mr. Baker sent a brief report that was quoted in the House of Commons by Francis Pym, the foreign secretary, during a debate on the Falklands.

headline.main: LONDON TOLD ISLANDERS FACE NO HARDSHIP

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: British marines and scientists deported early today by Argentina to Uruguay walked on the beach and played with a soccer ball but made no comments to the press.   The 29 marines, captured during the Argentine invasion of the Falkland and South...
docs.lead_paragraph: British marines and scientists deported early today by Argentina to Uruguay walked on the beach and played with a soccer ball but made no comments to the press. The 29 marines, captured during the Argentine invasion of the Falkland and South Georgia Islands April 2, and 13 scientists from the British Antarctic research station were to fly to London Monday on a British Air Force jet. The marines were the last of the British contingent that surrendered to Argentine forces.

headline.main: British Troops and Scientists From Falklands Are Deported

docs.snippet: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher consulted with colleagues by telephone tonight as anxiety mounted here over the continuing deadlock in peace negotiations in Buenos Aires.   The Prime Minister's urgent calls, placed from her office at 10 Downing...
docs.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher consulted with colleagues by telephone tonight as anxiety mounted here over the continuing deadlock in peace negotiations in Buenos Aires. The Prime Minister's urgent calls, placed from her office at 10 Downing Street, marked the second time in the last 24 hours she had canvassed the opinion of Government members on the Falklands crisis. Last night she met for two hours with the members of the crisis cabinet - Francis Pym, the Foreign Secretary, John Nott, the Defense Minister, and William Whitelaw, the Home Secretary, who also acts as the Deputy Prime Minister. For the last three days, Mrs. Thatcher has been awaiting word from Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. on the outcome of his talks with the Argentine junta. Late tonight, she was still waiting.

headline.main: MRS. THATCHER CONSULTS URGENTLY WITH COLLEAGUES

byline.original: By R.W. APPLE Jr., Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Thomas O. Enders, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, told a House subcommittee today that Nicaragua was ''engaged in a campaign of destabilization'' in El Salvador. He said ''substantial levels'' of arms were continuing to enter...
docs.lead_paragraph: Thomas O. Enders, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, told a House subcommittee today that Nicaragua was ''engaged in a campaign of destabilization'' in El Salvador. He said ''substantial levels'' of arms were continuing to enter that country. He also said the United States had evidence for the first time that Cuban intelligence authorities were using drug trafficking as a guise for running guns for guerrillas in Latin America. Referring to charges of Cuban involvement in the case of a Colombian narcotics dealer, Jaime Guillot Lara, now in custody in Mexico, he said, ''Until now we have tended to think of Cuba as puritanical on the drug issue.''

headline.main: SALVADOR ARMS FLOW CONTINUES, ENDERS SAYS

byline.original: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Outplayed in the first set, Jimmy Connors rebounded for a 4-6, 6-2, 6-1 victory over Sandy Mayer today and a berth in the final of the $370,000 Alan King Tennis Classic.   The top-seeded Connors, who leads the Volvo Grand Prix standing, will face...
docs.lead_paragraph: Outplayed in the first set, Jimmy Connors rebounded for a 4-6, 6-2, 6-1 victory over Sandy Mayer today and a berth in the final of the $370,000 Alan King Tennis Classic. The top-seeded Connors, who leads the Volvo Grand Prix standing, will face Sandy's younger brother, Gene Mayer, in Sunday's final. Gene defeated Mark Edmondson, 6-0, 6-1, in the second semifinal. The first prize is $60,000.
